comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think this photo shows the "first" Sydney Station - see www.sydneytrains.info/about/history/central_station_in-depth - which would make the photo earlier than 1874 when the "second" station opened. After 1869 when the Mortuary station was completed. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] I think it is from St Paul's too. See this very detailed interactive 1895 map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=...

comment.author: 81028427@N04
comment._content: But the photo set includes this photograph of the "second" Sydney Station?

comment.author: 81028427@N04

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/81028427@N04] The picture in the UK Archives shows the second terminal station - technically the 'first' Sydney station - the first terminal being roughly where Redfern station now is. The 'second' Sydney station - or third terminal is the current station in Railway Square. 

It is interesting that as early as 1848 (seven years before the opening of the line to Granville/Parramatta) the Sydney Railway Company was agitating for the government to approve extending the line to what we now know as Belmore Park (Hay Street). The objective being to build the original terminal there and thus a couple of miles closer to the city. It is a matter of history that Central Railway (the 'third' terminal) was opened in 1906, some 58 years after the proposal and in virtually the same spot as the 1848 proposal!

Cynics would say that this set the precedent for future decision making - the completion of the City Circle in 1956, the Eastern Suburbs Railway in 1977 and so on! Let's hope the second railway crossing of Sydney Harbour bringing the North West Rail Link into the city and beyond isn't delayed much beyond 2020!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81028427@N04] A great article - what a pity it wasn't accompanied by a photographer!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81028427@N04] It may/must be an earlier photo (from a series of the Mortuary Station) recycled.  If the "second" station was built, its end arches would show up well, as in other photos.  There don't seem to be many photos of the "first" station,  I suppose because it was really just a tin shed.   It is fun trying to work it all out - like time travel from the comfort of an armchair.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] John - I think you are a bit confused with the stations and locations - have a look at this site - www.sydneytrains.info/about/history/central_station_in-depth

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81028427@N04] Here is a picture of the first "Sydney Station" - ie the first Sydney terminal station - it was known as Redfern

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/9327762720/]

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I was basing my evidence on the location of the first station on the 1848 map (signed by Charles Cowper) which I erroneously thought shows the 'original station' to the south of Cleveland Street - in fact it shows the station to the north of the Cleveland Street bridge. Thus very happy to stand corrected on the location as described on the SydneyTrains website - this is corroborated by the roof of the Exhibition Building which appears over the roof of the station buildings in the above picture.

The point I'm making is that there have been three Sydney terminal stations. The first two were known as Redfern - the last (and current) Sydney Terminal is now known as Sydney Central Station.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] On the 1848 map, there is a mark for "SIGNAL STATION" (not 'original station') - see my note there. www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5353105184/
